Starting at the tender age of eight, Chef Tony Priolo has been immersed in authentic Italian cooking. From his Sicilian grandmother’s kitchen in Chicago to a two-Michelin-starred restaurant in Tuscany, Tony has developed a very distinct and clean rustic cooking style, and even had a hand in the development of Mariano’s signature Sicilian pizza and sauce. Today he focuses on finding the best ingredients possible to elevate his recipes and provide guests of Piccolo Sogno with a true Italian dining experience.

Tony's restaurants

Piccolo Sogno
Piccolo Sogno Due
Chef Priolo’s recipe

Ragu di Bolognese

reheating pasta

I recommend if you are cooking pasta with the intention of left overs, let it cool without rinsing or tossing it in olive oil. then reheat it in the sauce after the sauce is already hot.

chicken liver

Chef Tony’s little secret to creating a great bolognese sauce is to add chicken liver along with veal, pork and beef.

recommended olive oil

My favorite is the Sicilian olive oil from Piccolo Sogno. I cook with it at the restaurants and in my home, and it’s sold at Mariano’s.

Q & A

Which Mariano’s do you shop?

I usually shop at the Mariano’s Harwood Heights and also Mariano’s Park Ridge.

What is your favorite department at Mariano’s?

A secret passion of mine is the baked good section. I fill my cart with fresh croissants, muffins, and chocolate chip butter cookies.

What type of pasta noodle do you recommend?

Penne rigate is a good choice because it holds sauce well.

We’ve heard you say that pasta shouldn’t be rinsed after it’s cooked. Why?

To rinse the pasta after it is cooked is like a sin. The starch that adheres to the pasta after it is cooked keeps the sauce stuck on the pasta.

What’s your secret to a great tomato sauce?

I cook the tomato sauce for 2-3 hours, stirring occasionally. The concentrated tomato flavor of a zesty marinara is the best.

What kind of tomatoes do you use in your sauce?

For pasta sauce, I use the San Marzano brand from Italy. It comes in cans and Mariano's sells it. It’s the same brand I use in my restaurants.

What’s your favorite thing to cook at home?

Besides pasta, I am a big fan of making soups - especially chicken soup.

We heard you helped with the development of Mariano’s popular Sicilian pizza. True story?

I helped develop the dough, the sauce and cooking method. The recipes are authentic. Also, they wanted a crispy crust so I specified the pans to hold heat and keep the pizza crisp.
